awd_titl_txt: RAPID:   Multi-Hazard Performance of Load Bearing Wall Systems: A Case Study in Haiti following the January 2010 Earthquake and October 2016 Hurricane Matthew
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) will enable a team of wind, coastal, and structural engineers from the University of Notre Dame and the University of Florida to conduct a forensic analysis across the Tiburon Peninsula of Haiti to examine the performance of low-rise construction during the October 2016 Hurricane Matthew.  Strengthening community resilience to natural disasters depends critically on improving construction practices across a private sector dominated by low-rise buildings. This issue becomes particularly urgent for coastal communities, where hurricane risk is escalating under changing sea levels and climate conditions. Historically, masonry load bearing wall systems had served as a trusted mode of low-rise construction in such settings. For example, builders in the southeastern United States commonly use masonry for churches, schools, commercial buildings, and even residences. Despite their popularity, the vulnerabilities in these systems to natural hazards can be significant, particularly within states that have yet to enact statewide minimum building standards. Regrettably, these vulnerabilities are only revealed under extreme wind, wave, and storm surge loads associated with the passage of major hurricanes. This makes the forensic analysis of building failures during major hurricanes a critical source of knowledge to improve the design state-of-the-art.   

The passage of Hurricane Matthew over Haiti in October 2016 provides an opportunity to conduct a forensic analysis of low-rise masonry building performance under one of the most significant hurricanes in recent history. This setting includes construction preferences that facilitate unique comparative analyses of variables known to influence performance of masonry buildings under wind, wave, and storm surge. Moreover, the fact that portions of Haiti have recently undergone reconstruction, following the devastating January 2010 earthquake in that country, with greater vigilance toward seismic detailing, furthers the potential for impact, as there has been no prior opportunity in the United States to explore the in-situ performance of structures under multiple significant hazards in a limited time period (strong earthquake followed by major hurricane). Through a combination of aerial and ground-based techniques, the multi-institutional team will collect perishable data to answer the following questions: (1) How did traditional masonry structural systems perform under hurricane wind, wave, and storm surge? (2) How did the new structural systems that have emerged in response to the 2010 earthquake and aseismically detailed traditional masonry systems perform in this major hurricane? (3) How does the performance of traditional masonry load bearing walls in Hurricane Matthew compare to that observed in the 2010 earthquake? How can this inform future multi-hazard designs? These insights will contribute to advancing more resilient, multi-hazard construction practices to reduce future losses of life and property.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
Strengthening community resilience to natural disasters depends critically on improving construction practices for low-rise buildings. This issue becomes particularly urgent for coastal communities where hurricane risk is escalating under a changing climate and rising seas. Historically, masonry load bearing wall systems had served as a trusted mode of low-rise construction in such settings. For example, builders in the southeastern United States commonly employ masonry for churches, schools, commercial buildings and even residences. Despite their popularity, the vulnerabilities in these systems can be significant. Regrettably, these vulnerabilities are only revealed under extreme wind, wave and storm surge loads associated with the passage of major hurricanes. This makes the forensic analysis of building failures during these events a critical source of knowledge to improve safe coastal construction practices. Unfortunately, there have been few opportunities for such real-world validation in the United States, particularly given the zoning regulations that prohibit building in such close proximity to shorelines where strong waves form.

The passage of Hurricane Matthew over Haiti on October 4, 2016 provided an opportunity to conduct such a forensic analysis for low-rise masonry buildings under one of the most significant hurricanes prior to the active 2017 hurricane season. This setting includes construction preferences that facilitate unique comparative analyses of factors known to influence performance of masonry buildings under wind, wave and storm surge, as well as settlement patterns that regrettably expose this buildings to direct wave action. In order to learn from this devastating event, a team of wind, coastal and structural engineers joined a team of Haitian investigators to conduct field reconnaissance from November 18 to 24, 2016. The investigation canvassed Haiti’s southern coastal communities of Les Cayes, Les Anglais, Port Salut, Chardonnières and La Cahouane, as well as the northern coastal communities of Jérémie, Bonbon and Abricot. The team documented the intensity of wind, wave and storm surge in each of these communities and specifically evaluated the performance of low-rise masonry construction under these damaging forces, collecting measurements and photos on the ground while drones gathered imagery overhead.

Through these efforts in Haiti, the team was able to document the significant level of inundation in these communities (in excess of 8 m or 26 feet in some regions) and document the damage to foundations and masonry structures under this strong wave action. This investigation revealed the unique configurations of masonry structures and site conditions that were capable of withstanding such intense wave loads. For structures further from the coast, the primary damage was due to strong winds exploiting weaknesses in the roof system. However, the team was able to similarly identify metal roof systems that could even withstand winds speeding up as the hurricane passed over steep hillsides, as well as variations on hurricane straps that can maintain the connection between the roof and walls under Category 4 winds. More importantly, the investigation revealed what configurations of masonry low-rise buildings could be susceptible to catastrophic failure due to hurricane wind loads, advising strategies to retrofit such structures or policy recommendations that could mitigate catastrophic collapse of these buildings in future hurricanes. Finally, the investigation also evaluated the performance of critical facilities like hospitals and schools used as shelters during evacuations, identifying potential vulnerabilities as well as documenting configurations that provided the resilience necessary to maintain safety and security of occupants sheltering during the storm.

Such scientific findings will help to inform adaptation strategies for coastal communities in the United States and worldwide, as increasingly larger portions of the global population are exposed to the effects of sea level rise and intense hurricanes. Beyond these potentials to reduce societal vulnerability to future hurricanes, this project remained mindful of the need to build the human and technical infrastructure necessary to continue such vital assessments in the future. Specifically, the team trained and mentored populations in the US and Haiti in not only the fundamentals of coordinated structural assessments after storms, but in how to incorporate the knowledge from these investigations into their ongoing work with coastal communities, especially those recovering from Hurricane Matthew in Haiti. Moreover, this project has helped to strengthen the US structural engineering community’s capacity to respond after such disasters, using the team’s experiences in this event to inform the design of the new NSF National Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI)’s support for rapid reconnaissance efforts.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/25/2018
Modified by: Tracy L Kijewski-Correa

Images (1 of )
  • (left to right) Back Row: Lamarre Presuma, Scott Schiff, Onel Dossou, David Prevatt, Michael Wilson; Front Row: Kwasi Perry, Jac Lubin, Alexandros Taflanidis, Edson Jean, Tracy Kijewski-Correa, Gede Jean Benoit, Brunie St-Fort and Andrew Kennedy.
    Andrew Kennedy
    Creative Commons
    Tracy L Kijewski-Correa
    US-Haitian Reconnaissance Team in Hurricane Matthew (2016, Haiti)
  • Wind damage to masonry homes in Bonbon, Haiti (a) aerial photo showing only roof damage to the homes with ring beam and collapse of homes without ring beams; (b) collapse of home due to roof uplift masonry walls constructed without ring beam (note home with ring beam in background is undamaged).
    Kwasi Perry, Alexandros Taflanidis
    Creative Commons
    Tracy L Kijewski-Correa
    Performance of Ring Beam Details in Hurricane Matthew (2016, Haiti)
  • Failure of masonry walls instigated by roof uplift in (a) long-span two-story confined masonry wall with no interior partitions in home in Port Salut, Haiti [note the bowing the second floor wall] and (b) failure of slender wall at home on hillside in Jérémie, Haiti.
    Kwasi Perry, Alexandros Taflanidis
    Creative Commons
    Tracy L Kijewski-Correa
    Wind-Induced Masonry Load Bearing Wall Failures for Atypical Geometries in Hurricane Matthew (2016, Haiti)
  • High elevation wave run-up in a cliffed region near Roche-à-Bateaux, Haiti: (a) evidence of debris moved by storm; (b) example of undamaged masonry home [note boulder moved next to the house, significant scouring of foundation and windows blown out due to surge and wave action up to third floor].
    Andrew Kennedy, Alexandros Taflanidis
    Creative Commons
    Tracy L Kijewski-Correa
    Resilient Coastal Masonry Construction in Hurricane Matthew (Haiti, 2016)
  • Wave damage at nursing school located on the outskirts of Côteaux, Haiti. Waves destroyed two buildings but left another one, sheltered by small vegetation intact [that building experienced only loss of roof cover due to strong winds]: (a) ground photo and (b) aerial photo.
    Alexandros Taflanidis, Kwasi Perry
    Creative Commons
    Tracy L Kijewski-Correa
    Natural Mitigative Features in Hurricane Matthew (Haiti, 2016)
